audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker addressing the audience and stating that he will be sharing a video about minor aspects of his life because viewers want to see that sort of content. He mentions installing OpenBSD on a computer. Then, he shifts focus to a stool, reminiscing about using it as a child to brush his teeth, indicating the stool has been in his family for a long time.

The clip starts with a male speaker talking about OpenBSD and his desktop, indicating he's had it for a while. He explains he doesn't use it much, preferring his ThinkPad. He then asks why he installed OpenBSD and what he's looking for from it, clarifying that viewers shouldn't expect many OpenBSD videos from him, but mentioning he might do some.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that he "canceled internet at my house." He explains that he's unlikely to do anything fancy with something, mentioning he might just "toy around with it." He then clarifies that he installed OpenBSD partially as an "experimentation." The audio contains no music or background sounds.

The audio clip features a male speaker who has been using Linux, and transitions to speak about using OpenBSD, suggesting that it is not "supposed to be that different". His tone is casual but critical as he complains about the direction of Linux and its distributions "screwing things up". He notes that OpenBSD people are "better minded" than many in the Linux community. Overall, the audio sounds like a monologue from someone who is familiar with technology and expressing their opinion.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing previous plans and then stating that he has decided to try OpenBSD for specific reasons. He mentions verifying that it's OpenBSD using a command, and notes that it might be backward for the listener. He then mentions that he will probably play around with it, and that he has only installed it. The speaker expresses frustration over having to sit on the floor, then the clip cuts off.

The clip starts with a single male speaker describing his experience with a new operating system, noting that he's "basically done is install a couple programs" and realized that some commands he knows from Linux aren't on OpenBSD. He expresses a desire to make his scripts universal, considering POSIX compliance and avoiding GNU options. He mentions that some things will be "hard to live without" specific commands, highlighting differences between BSD and other systems.
A male speaker begins discussing the OpenBSD installation, specifically noting its command-line options. He explains that the installation involves an "install script" that presents yes/no questions.

One male speaker begins by stating his dislike for something. He then expresses a preference for the Arch Linux way of installing things, explaining that in OpenBSD, while the actions are similar, the user isn't running the commands directly, but trusting a script. He shares how he had to learn that TTYs work differently and he is still learning basic things. The speaker then reiterates his preference for an installation process closer to that of Arch Linux, where the user runs the commands directly. Finally, he says "but I don't know" before the clip ends.

The audio clip starts with one male speaker expressing his confusion about OpenBSD, mentioning that the people who use it are "more tech savvy than Linux users", and that he would expect them to be capable of running certain commands. He also mentions that the historical installer doesn't give the desired options, but that it "installed very fine", and mentioning the firmware.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing his experience with Wi-Fi functionality on a device running OpenBSD, acknowledging he hasn't tested it yet and doesn't know the relevant commands. He then explains that he's installed OpenBSD and is experimenting, without committing to anything specific. His tone is conversational and exploratory.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the possibility of successfully "porting over" his "builds of stuff", suggesting potential positive outcomes. His tone is speculative. He prefaces his statement with a conditional "if" clause, indicating a contingency.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the potential of an operating system on his laptop. He explains he didn't install it because OpenBSD, as far as he knows, is not compatible with EXT4 partitions, which he uses for Linux. He goes on to describe his usual file system preferences, mentioning NTFS for external drives. Concluding the audio, the speaker acknowledges he's rambling and expresses intent to try out the operating system and see how it goes.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who begins by stating his opinion that he identifies with the way OpenBSD people look at things and how they've organized their operating system. He contrasts this with the stupidity of Linux. Despite this, he expresses contentment with his current Linux distribution, Artix, and its setup. He mentions this being the first time in years that he's bothered to try another operating system for himself. He occasionally tries operating systems out when helping others install Linux. He concludes by suggesting he thinks about his personal experience.

The audio clip features a single male speaker who expresses apathy, saying "I don't really care about this stuff anymore, but I'm doing it anyway." He mentions creating a video in case someone cares, possibly because "people watch this channel" and expect "technology stuff." He concludes the clip by saying, "Okay, that's it. See you guys next time." His tone is conversational and somewhat self-deprecating.
